The Negro on campus Racial issues down since 1954
By HOLLACE GOLDBERG
Since the Supreme Court’s school desegregation decision in 1954, the University has slowly dropped all racial tones from its hiring, housing and admissions policies.
In 1964 the Board of Regents ordered that questions of race be deleted from application forms. A student's race could be requested only after he had been admitted to the University, and then only for statistical pur- poses.
The housing office also deleted race questions from its forms, but continued to request pictures of students seeking dormitory rooms. Negro students felt this was done to avoid inter-racial room assignments. Though such a policy was never spelled out, observation indicated this to be true.
Under housing policies initiat- ed this fall, no student’s picture is requested. Housing Director Margaret Lloyd said that previous housing directors might have used the pictures to match up Negro roommates, but her present policy forbids such “sub- jective" assignments. “It is my determination that we eliminate anything that smacks of discrimination," Miss Lloyd declared. “I can’t see that the color of the skin has anything more to do with a person than the color of their hair."
Roommates, she explained, are at present matched objectively. “If you don’t request a room- mate and a hall, you are assigned by electronic data processes." The computer, she noted, is a “random" not a “racial" machine.
If a white student rooming with a Negro complains of “roommate incompatibility" due to race, Miss Lloyd handles this complaint much as she would any other. The students are asked to try to work things out. But if the situation remains unstatisfactory, the "complaining student is moved." Miss Lloyd added that such problems are often “more pa- rental than student," and arise infrequently.
Off-campus housing is another matter. Negroes have always had difficulty securing rooms and apartments near campus. According to the testimony of Bill Jonas, a commuter, he and another Negro submitted an ap- plication in person for an apart- ment, leaving a $5O room deposit. Hearing no word after a month, “we called H.G. Smithy Realtors and they in turn said ‘hold on a minute.' No one ever came back to the phone," related Jones.
"A week later, we received (through the mall) our request for application—-denied. We called, and a week later our check came back. We had no time to raise any issues about it.
"After that, well, I Just stayed in Washington with my aunt."
According to off-campus hous- ing director Doyal P. Royal, the University aids students seeking off-campus housing by keeping a "public list of public facilities." However, until last July that list included many houses and apart- ments that were closed to colored students.
Months of protests, picket lines, pressure groups and politics forced the University to revise its “public" list over the summer of 1966. A new form, sent out to area landlords, stated: “We cannot accept your listing if your only reason for not accept- ing the student is because of race, color, national origin or reli- gion."
Reflecting on the new policy, Royal said, “Last summer we decided to try to please every- body and neutralize the card." As a result, last year's 400- apartment list has dwindled. "Only one large apartment house remains on the list," he said.
Removed from housing office policies is the University's ath- letics program. In his depart- ment, asserted Director of Athletics William W. Cobey, “the policy has been simply that any student enrolled at the University is welcome to come out for athletics." Ball players are not chosen by their color, they must qualify academically and athleti cally.
Furthermore, the athletic de- partment keeps no record of an athlete’s race. Cobey could not recall the date when the first Negro athlete competed for the University in intercollegiate var- sity ball. However, a perusal of Terrapin yearbooks shows that the swim team was the first to integrate, in 1963, with the addi tion of Negro swimmer Jason Williams.
The football team followed the next year. In fall, 1964, Darryl Hill played on the varsity squad. Last year in football, Ernie Torain played halfback. He was joined this year by Alvin Lee, also a halfback.
Bill Jones played basketball last year, and this year Pete Johnson is also playing on the court. The track team has had Negro members since last year.
In another area, the hiring of employees, recruitment depends largely on state civil service requirements.
The University is an "equal opportunity" employer, reports George W. Fogg, director of personnel. "We have employed everyone (Negro) that is qualified for his job. We equalize white and Negro... We don’t favor either one or the other." Answering a query about the sparsity of Negro secretaries on campus, Fogg frankly conceded, “We have a lot of Negro secre- taries—-but we have a lot more white ones."
To recruit staff, Fogg's office advertises through local newspa- pers and employment agencies. If applicants meet state civil service requirements, they are interviewed by the Personnel Of- fice. Departments with vacancies interview several job candidates and choose one to fill the position. Once hired, the employees must fill out income tax papers, pay roll forms and a personal history questionnaire. The personal his- tory form includes a question on race.
“This is only for statistics," explained Fogg. “We never ask this until the person is hired." These racial statistics are re- quired by the Compliance Com- mittee of the State Fair Prac- tices Commission. The Univer sity must make a report to the Commission on the ratio of Negro and white employees. The first such report, which is presently being compiled, is due Jan. 15.
Hiring of faculty members is done largely at the departmental level. Nominations are generated by the department heads.
Here, related Fogg, qualifica- tions are very specific. Nomi nees are interviewed by R. Lee Hornbake, vice-president for academic affairs, and appoint- ments confirmed by the Board of Regents.
Hornbake stated that in re- cruiting faculty, “we are not try- ing to find people of any race. But," he added “qualified Negroes are in very short supply, since they are being sought after eagerly by many instructors."
He mentioned that two Negroes --an African assistant professor in G&P and an associate pro- fessor of education—-have been hired in the past two years to teach in College Park. However, as for the total number of Negro instructors on the University’s many campuses, Hornbake said, “I don’t know how many there are and honestly, I don't care. All I am interested in is good faculty."
Hornbake also dlsspelled a rumor that has been pervading the sociology department for the last twelve months. A Negro professor nominated by the sociology department did not complete his contract negotia- tions for a position. Rumors, however, persisted that the ad- ministration had dropped their offer due specifically to the ap- plicant’s race.
Hornbake explained what happened. The man, a “highly recommended" professor of an- thropology, told the University he had received “another offer from a West coast institution."
“He was a quality man, who had been in demand in a variety of places," testified Hornbake. “I did not infer from him that he felt that race had been a factor at all, in not accepting the Uni- versity bid."
To learn just how many Negroes the University employs in College Park, last spring the Personnel Office sent to all fac- ulty and staff a short personal history questionnaire. The data, as mentioned before, was being compiled for the State Fair Prac- tices Commission.
Resenting racial questions, many white faculty members an- swered by writing “Eskimo" or “mixed." But according to Fogg, “this was a misdirected form of liberalism. These people hinder- ed the cause that they were stand ing for."
The purpose of the survey was to indicate that the University does comply with the Civil Rights Act.

BILL JONES solemnly contemplates which card to throw as he plays pinochle in the Student Union. Jones, who commutes from Washington, tried unsuccessfully to rent an apartment close to campus.
CARMEN, a freshman who is a soprano member of the Madrigal Singers, looks through music books in the fourth floor stacks of the Library. She is the first Negro to sing with the Madrigals.
